The thing is, an Eisenhower's would have affected all the presidencies that followed, starting with Kennedy's.
But for the sake of your question. Obama, for sure. He would have been a much better candidate than Clinton and the Trump camp wouldn't have been able to smear him as easily. Clinton, I'm not so sure. There were quite a few scandals during the late part of his second term, which had an effect on Gores' campaign.

I don't think I was left with trust issues when I found out that Santa et. al. were my parents. In fact, I remember playing along for a while after finding out. It was fun. What I don't know, though, is whether my parents knew I had found out.
I think it's different in every case, and likely there will be other factors at play.

As an atheist parent of a 7 yo girl. No I don't think it's bad. BTW, I live in the Czech Republic where gifts aren't brought by Santa Claus, but by Jeek, baby Jesus. The ritual is that one of the parents gets the children out of the way while the other puts the presents under the tree (this takes place on Xmas Eve) and pretends nothing has happened. When the kids come back, they see all the presents under the tree and they get really excited, but they know they must wait until after dinner to see if they go what they asked Jeek in their letters. I love that, but I know that sooner rather than later she will find out that it was us all along, and we'll have to deal with it in the best possible way. I don't think she'll be disappointed, she's a smart girl and she'll understand it's part of the ritual.

WRITING.TEXT:
I've been an atheist for about 30 years, basically, since pretty much as long as I started thinking about the possibility of the existence of a deity, and I'm as convinced as anyone can be that there isn't one, nor has there ever been. Three years ago I was confronted with the death of my mother. I was there in her room when she drew her last breath. I was sad, of course, and I do miss her sometimes. Last year I lost a good friend, I person I knew only for a few years, but came to greatly respect and admire, I was also really sad when I heard about his passing. I still miss him sometimes, and recently I met with his daughter and his first wife and we had a great time sharing memories of him. In any case, I know that both of them as persons have ceased to exist the moment they stopped breathing.
It sucks to loose someone you care for, sure, but is the cycle of life and I accept it. It also makes life (the only one we have) all the more precious, and knowing there is nothing after that, makes you value even more, especially if you are aware that it can end at any time, no matter how healthy, young, good or smart you may be.

Con empleados es muy distinto. Si mal no me acuerdo, te retienen el 30%, o algo por el estilo ac. Es mucho mejor ser autnomo, por ese lado. Claro que tampoco tens ningn beneficio adicional, empezando por vacaciones pagas.

Hmm.... no s. Ac donde vivo, impuesto a las ganancias para empresas es de 19%, para autnomos es el 15%. Encima de eso, yo como autnomo tengo muchas ventajas: puedo declarar el 50% de mis ingresos como costos sin presentar ningn papel, puedo desgravar los intereses de la hipoteca (y creo que del leasing de un auto, pero no estoy seguro), tengo un descuento por mi hija. La ltima vez que pagu algo, debe haber sido hace 8-9 aos (ojo, tengo todos los papeles en orden).
Ahora, tambin tengo que pagar seguro mdico y seguridad social, que no son impuestos, pero funcionan de una manera bastante parecida, y el IVA por cada cosa que compro, No estoy registrado como agente de retencin (o contribuyente, no me acuerdo como es la figura legal ahora). As que podra decirse que pago bastante menos de lo que pagara si hiciese lo mismo, pero bajo una s.r.l. o s.h.
It's really, really funny. Their logic seems to be: Scientific fact = hoax, Indian tribe's legends = evidence.

IMO, the left failed in this election because they didn't have a decent candidate (really, Clinton was probably the worst possible choice, and I'm no Sanders supporter) and they had (and still keep) their heads really deep up their own self-righteous asses to realise that many people are legitimately mad at the system.

Y nadie lo niega. Pero comparemos: a menos que me equivoque, la industria automotriz argentina depende mayormente de la demanda del mercado interno, que en los ltimos 15-20 aos no ha sido de lo ms afluente. El campo siempre ha sido exportador (vivo en Europa y veo productos agrcolas argentinos, los nicos productos terminados de distribucin ms o menos amplia son los vinos).
Entonces me pregunto, si el campo dependiese nicamente del mercado interno, tendra los recursos para adquirir toda la tecnologa de punta con la que hoy cuenta?
A lo que voy es que no depende tanto de la modernizacin como otras industrias como, por ejemplo, la automotriz: Un choclo es un choclo, y no importa demasiado cmo lo hayas cultivado.
I thought the (anti-)Trump posts would stop after the election (regardless of result). I guess I was wrong.

El tema es que el campo no tiene tanta necesidad de acutalizarse o modernizarse. En tanto siga produciendo, va a poder seguir compitiendo en los mercados internacionales, a diferencia de muchas otras industrias.

It's not about respect, it's about business. Fancy restaurant owners have reasons to believe they can earn more money out of a bottle of wine than a bottle of beer, and there's a whole marketing mythology built around it. Whether the wine is treated with respect, will depend on the restaurant.
I live in Prague, CZ, and I've seen the respect beer gets at dive pub: taps always clean, beer served at a proper temperature, in clean, wet, chilled mugs in a way that will create the right head, and in one draw whenever possible, and tapsters proud to give you a well served pint.
I've also seen how wine is stored in fancy restaurants (in a cupboard near the kitchen, basically) and how much the mark-up is (500% over *retail* price, in some cases). Fancier/more expensive doesn't automatically mean more respect.
Fucks to give are a scarce commodity. Use them carefully.

The main problem being that:
The price of a beer in a bar was calculated using the average price of local and imported 33cl and 50 cl draught beers in several major hotel chains worldwide.
Which tends to be a lot more expensive than what your average bar will charge you. In Prague, for instance, it doesn't make any sense. More than 4 USD for a beer? That's about 100 CZK. I know places where you can have 2 l of beer for that sort of money!
Even the supermarket price is arguable at best. They take into account 0.3l bottles, when many of the major local brands are available only in 0.5l bottles (or bigger).
Source: I live in Prague and have written a pub guide of the city.

Rural areas tend to be more closed and homogeneous communities (everybody knows each other) that aren't much affected by outside cultural influences.
Urban areas, especially large ones, are by default heterogeneous, diverse and in constant flow, with a lot more access to other forms of culture (and therefore, more affected by outside cultural influences).They are also much less bound to tradition--a farmer is more likely to expect his children to carry on with the farm than, say, a free-lance translator will expect his daughter to become a translator, too.

WRITING.TEXT: Lamentablemente, no conozco a nadie. S que hay cursos para extranjeros, pero no tengo idea ni de los precios ni de que tan buenos puedan ser. Fijate en Expats.cz o en alguna otra pgina parecida.
En espaol hace rato que se viene usando, y es ms cmodo que el nombre formal.

En promedio, el equivalente a 8-9 EUR/pgina con agencias. Con clientes privados: 12-13. Pero depende tambin de qu tan grande es la traduccin y los plazos.
Traduzco del checo al ingls o espaol. De vez en cuando me mandan algo ingls - espaol.

S. A veces me mandan traducciones del eslovaco y tengo amigos eslovacos con los que hablo normalmente, aunque si estoy un poco cansado a veces me pierdo. La pronunciacin es muy diferente y palabras que son distintas.
En Argentina s que se cobraba por palabra, yo vivo en Chequia y ac se suele pagar por pgina estndar (1800 caracteres, incl. espacios), pero algunos pagan por palabra.

Aprend checo por smosis :) Vivo en Praga hace 14 aos y medio. Tengo un par de clientes propios, pero la mayora de los laburos vienen por agencia, trabajo 20 casi; algunas mandan un par de laburos por ao, otras mandan ms seguido.
El tema de no saber cunto vas a ganar, o que las vacaciones "te salen dos veces ms caras", rompe un poco las pelotas, s (y creo que es comn a todos los laburos free-lance), pero no tanto como esas semanas que me rasco el orto hasta el jueves a la tarde y de golpe me empiezan a llamar todos para que les haga una traduccin para el lunes. Pero bueno, son los gajes. y no me puedo quejar; en promedio gano lo suficiente para vivir cmodo (aunque sin demasiados lujos) y por lo general, manejo mis tiempos. La mayora de los das pego un tirn hasta el medioda, corto un par de horas y me voy a dar una vuelta y tomarme una birra y/o a buscar a mi hija al cole, y cuando llego a casa a la tarde laburo una o dos horas ms antes de ponerme a preparar la cena. Me gusta mucho el laburo, no soy un tipo ambicioso y me viene fenmeno.
Otra cosa en donde hasta ahora he tenido mucha suerte: todos garpan y al da

Yo tambin soy traductor. Y no lo veo aburrido, hay veces que me divierte el desafo de convertir un texto complejo del checo al espaol o el ingls; puede ser casi como un rompecabezas lingstico, y de tanto en tanto me cae algo interesante para traducir. Adems, lo hago tranquilo desde casa, como mucho seis horas por da; por lo general, aunque trabajo bastante los fines de semana y, adems de todo, garpa bastante bien, teniendo en cuenta el nivel de exigencia y la falta de estrs.

Traductor. Es simple: un cliente me manda un laburo, acordamos la fecha de entrega y el precio por pgina. En tanto cumpla con el plazo, cmo, cundo y dnde lo hago, y cuntas horas por da le dedico, queda a mi total criterio. Una vez que lo entregu, si no hay problema, me puedo olvidar del laburo ese hasta fin de mes, cuando lo facturo.

The difference here is that this is the coat of arms of a family, not a town or region. Anyway, according to Wikipedia, the Turk's head is there because:
In 1599, Adolf von Schwarzenberg became an Imperial Count, and was given by the emperor a quarter showing the head of a Turk being pecked by a raven. This was to commemorate Adolf's conquest on 19 March 1598 of the Turkish-held fortress and city Gyr. The German name of the Hungarian town is Raab, which means raven.

Oh, yeah. It does. Even here in Czechia. And the same can be said about every beer that is available both bottled and on tap.
For PU in particular. bottles are more heavily pasteurised, injected with CO2 and usually exposed to the light and heating of supermarkets. Kegs, on the other hand may be unpasteurised (tanks are by default) and the beer inside is better protected from the elements, not to mention that the way it's dispensed can significantly affect the taste.

[The coat of arms of the Schwarzenberg family](http://www.almanachdegotha.org/sitebuildercontent/sitebuilderpictures/.pond/schwarzenberg_coat.jpg.w300h354.jpg) The lower right corner of the shield has a crow eating the eye of the head of a Turk.

It was when I was reading Stephen King's "It" for the second time. It was well past midnight, everyone was sleeping and the house was dark and quiet. It scared me shitless and I didn't want to go check out what it hell it had been. I turned off the light and tried to sleep. It was the glass top of the coffee table that had cracked for some reason.

I'm friends with several restaurant owners and managers, and some of their staff, too. I can't remember a single time where the question of tips, or lack thereof, has been discussed.
Of course servers like being tipped, but the situation here is radically different than in the U.S. Firstly, servers must be paid at least minimum wage. Secondly, in a market with very little unemployment (the Czech Rep. has the lowest rate in the EU, and there's virtually no unemployment in Prague) and A LOT of competition, smart owners know that having good, reliable staff is key to the success of their businesses, so they try to keep them happy and pay them something extra (usually, under the table). It is very common here, at least at places out of the centre, to see the same people working for years at a pub; that is always a good sign.
